screens.headline: Is 1.9% return in 30 days good or bad?
screens.text: Let's build the calculator every covered call trader uses. You'll see exactly how to calculate returns, breakevens, and annualized income - the math that separates profitable traders from losers.

screens.headline: The 3 Numbers That Matter
screens.text: Every covered call has three possible outcomes: (1) Max Profit if called away, (2) Income if expires, (3) Breakeven if stock drops. Knowing these numbers BEFORE you trade is the difference between gambling and strategy.

screens.headline: Calculation #1: Max Profit (Stock Called Away)
screens.description: When the stock goes ABOVE your strike and gets assigned
screens.formula_display: Max Profit = [(Strike - Cost Basis) Ã— 100] + (Premium Ã— 100)
teaching_points: Try $195 strike: Higher strike = more max profit
Try $2 premium: Lower premium = less total profit
This is your BEST case scenario

screens.headline: Calculation #2: Premium Income (Stock Stays Flat)
screens.description: When stock stays below strike - you keep shares + premium
screens.formula_display: Monthly Return = (Premium / Stock Price) Ã— (30 / Days)
teaching_points: Try 45 days: Longer duration = lower annualized return
Try $5 premium: Higher premium = better income
Most covered calls target 1-3% monthly return

screens.headline: Calculation #3: Breakeven & Downside Cushion
screens.description: How much can the stock drop before you lose money?
teaching_points: Premium provides a CUSHION on the downside
Try $175: Now you're losing despite the premium

screens.question: Stock is $200. You collect $4 premium. What's your breakeven price?
screens.explanation_correct: Perfect! $200 - $4 premium = $196 breakeven. Stock can drop 2% ($4) and you still don't lose money. That's your downside cushion!
screens.explanation_wrong: The premium you collected ($4) is yours to keep. So the stock needs to drop BELOW $196 before you actually lose money. $200 - $4 = $196.

screens.question: You want 2% monthly return. Stock is $150, premiums are $2 (30 days) or $4 (60 days). Which is better?
screens.explanation_correct: Correct! $2/$150 = 1.33% in 30 days. $4/$150 = 2.67% in 60 days = 1.33%/month. They're the same monthly rate, but the 30-day option gives you more flexibility to adjust your strategy sooner.
